And Chu-bu spake unto Sheemish as speak the
gods, moving no lips nor yet disturbing the

8585.90.text:
silence, saying, "There is dirt upon thy head,
O Sheemish." All night long he muttered again

8594.75.text:
and again, "there is dirt upon Sheemish's
head." And when it was dawn and voices were

8601.33.text:
heard far off, Chu-bu became exultant with
Earth's awakening things, and cried out till

8608.35.text:
the sun was high, "Dirt, dirt, dirt, upon
the head of Sheemish," and at noon he said,

8617.46.text:
"So Sheemish would be a god." Thus was Sheemish
confounded.

8624.87.text:
And with Tuesday one came and washed his head
with rose-water, and he was worshipped again

8630.19.text:
when they sang "There is also Sheemish." And
yet was Chu-bu content, for he said, "The

8639.85.text:
head of Sheemish has been defiled," and again,
"His head was defiled, it is enough." And

8649.06.text:
one evening lo! there was dirt on the head
of Chu-bu also, and the thing was perceived

8659.24.text:
It is not with the gods as it is with men.
We are angry one with another and turn from

8664.93.text:
our anger again, but the wrath of the gods
is enduring. Chu-bu remembered and Sheemish

8671.87.text:
did not forget. They spake as we do not speak,
in silence yet heard of each other, nor were

8680.72.text:
their thoughts as our thoughts. We should
not judge them merely by human standards.

8687.75.text:
All night long they spake and all night said
these words only: "Dirty Chu-bu," "Dirty Sheemish."

8696.18.text:
"Dirty Chu-bu," "Dirty Sheemish," all night
long. Their wrath had not tired at dawn, and

8705.11.text:
neither had wearied of his accusation. And
gradually Chu-bu came to realize that he was

8712.13.text:
nothing more than the equal of Sheemish. All
gods are jealous, but this equality with the

8718.87.text:
upstart Sheemish, a thing of painted wood
a hundred years newer than Chu-bu, and this

8724.82.text:
worship given to Sheemish in Chu-bu's own
temple, were particularly bitter. Chu-bu was

8731.99.text:
jealous even for a god; and when Tuesday came
again, the third day of Sheemish's worship,

8739.15.text:
Chu-bu could bear it no longer. He felt that
his anger must be revealed at all costs, and

8746.82.text:
he returned with all the vehemence of his
will to achieving a little earthquake. The

8753.36.text:
worshippers had just gone from his temple
when Chu-bu settled his will to attain this

8758.56.text:
miracle. Now and then his meditations were
disturbed by that now familiar dictum, "Dirty

8767.27.text:
Chu-bu," but Chu-bu willed ferociously, not
even stopping to say what he longed to say

8773.96.text:
and had already said nine hundred times, and
presently even these interruptions ceased.

8781.58.text:
They ceased because Sheemish had returned
to a project that he had never definitely

8786.86.text:
abandoned, the desire to assert himself and
exalt himself over Chu-bu by performing a

8793.99.text:
miracle, and the district being volcanic he
had chosen a little earthquake as the miracle

8801.11.text: most easily accomplished by a small god.

8805.42.text:
Now an earthquake that is commanded by two
gods has double the chance of fulfilment than

8810.81.text:
when it is willed by one, and an incalculably
greater chance than when two gods are pulling

8817.43.text:
different ways; as, to take the case of older
and greater gods, when the sun and the moon

8823.94.text:
pull in the same direction we have the biggest
tides.

8828.30.text:
Chu-bu knew nothing of the theory of tides,
and was too much occupied with his miracle

8835.06.text:
to notice what Sheemish was doing. And suddenly
the miracle was an accomplished thing.

8843.05.text:
It was a very local earthquake, for there
are other gods than Chu-bu or even Sheemish,

8848.98.text:
and it was only a little one as the gods had
willed, but it loosened some monoliths in

8854.36.text:
a colonnade that supported one side of the
temple and the whole of one wall fell in,

8861.46.text:
and the low huts of the people of that city
were shaken a little and some of their doors

8866.17.text:
were jammed so that they would not open; it
was enough, and for a moment it seemed that

8873.00.text:
it was all; neither Chu-bu nor Sheemish commanded
there should be more, but they had set in

8880.71.text:
motion an old law older than Chu-bu, the law
of gravity that that colonnade had held back

8889.25.text:
for a hundred years, and the temple of Chu-bu
quivered and then stood still, swayed once

8897.66.text:
and was overthrown, on the heads of Chu-bu
and Sheemish.

8904.96.text:
No one rebuilt it, for nobody dared to near
such terrible gods. Some said that Chu-bu

8911.32.text:
wrought the miracle, but some said Sheemish,
and thereof schism was born. The weakly amiable,

8919.84.text:
alarmed by the bitterness of rival sects,
sought compromise and said that both had wrought

8926.10.text:
it, but no one guessed the truth that the
thing was done in rivalry.

8932.07.text:
And a saying arose, and both sects held this
belief in common, that whoso toucheth Chu-bu

8938.19.text: shall die or whoso looketh upon Sheemish.

8942.37.text:
That is how Chu-bu came into my possession
when I travelled once beyond the hills of

8947.63.text:
Ting. I found him in the fallen temple of
Chu-bu with his hands and toes sticking up

8953.37.text:
out of the rubbish, lying upon his back, and
in that attitude just as I found him I keep

8960.60.text:
him to this day on my mantlepiece, as he is
less liable to be upset that way. Sheemish

8967.22.text: was broken, so I left him where he was.

8971.67.text:
And there is something so helpless about Chu-bu
with his fat hands stuck up in the air that

8977.15.text:
sometimes I am moved out of compassion to
bow down to him and pray, saying, "O Chu-bu,

8983.74.text: thou that made everything, help thy servant."

8988.15.text:
Chu-bu cannot do much, though once I am sure
that at a game of bridge he sent me the ace

8993.76.text:
of trumps after I had not held a card worth
having for the whole of the evening. And chance

8999.54.text:
alone could have done as much as that for
me. But I do not tell this to Chu-bu.

9016.64.text:
The old man in the Oriental-looking robe was
being moved on by the police, and it was this

9023.17.text:
that attracted to him and the parcel under
his arm the attention of Mr. Sladden, whose

9029.66.text:
livelihood was earned in the emporium of Messrs.
Mergin and Chater, that is to say in their

9038.93.text:
Mr. Sladden had the reputation of being the
silliest young man in Business; a touch of

9045.31.text:
romance—a mere suggestion of it—would
send his eyes gazing away as though the walls

9050.21.text:
of the emporium were of gossamer and London
itself a myth, instead of attending to customers.

9058.06.text:
Merely the fact that the dirty piece of paper
that wrapped the old man's parcel was covered

9063.26.text:
with Arabic writing was enough to give Mr.
Sladden the idea of romance, and he followed

9070.17.text:
until the little crowd fell off and the stranger
stopped by the kerb and unwrapped his parcel

9076.30.text:
and prepared to sell the thing that was inside
it. It was a little window in old wood with

9083.94.text:
small panes set in lead; it was not much more
than a foot in breadth and was under two feet

9090.04.text:
long. Mr. Sladden had never before seen a
window sold in the street, so he asked the

9099.83.text:
"Its price is all you possess," said the old
man.

9105.27.text:
"Where did you get it?" said Mr. Sladden,
for it was a strange window.

9111.42.text:
"I gave all that I possessed for it in the
streets of Baghdad."

9117.11.text: "Did you possess much?" said Mr. Sladden.

9120.91.text:
"I had all that I wanted," he said, "except
this window."

9127.63.text:
"It must be a good window," said the young
man.

9132.18.text: "It is a magical window," said the old one.

9136.27.text:
"I have only ten shillings on me, but I have
fifteen-and-six at home."

9141.44.text: The old man thought for a while.

9144.95.text:
"Then twenty-five-and-sixpence is the price
of the window," he said.

9150.30.text:
It was only when the bargain was completed
and the ten shillings paid and the strange

9155.29.text:
old man was coming for his fifteen-and-six
and to fit the magical window into his only

9161.15.text:
room that it occurred to Mr. Sladden's mind
that he did not want a window. And then they

9169.73.text:
were at the door of the house in which he
rented a room, and it seemed too late to explain.

9176.49.text:
The stranger demanded privacy when he fitted
up the window, so Mr. Sladden remained outside

9182.61.text:
the door at the top of a little flight of
creaky stairs. He heard no sound of hammering.

9190.14.text:
And presently the strange old man came out
with his faded yellow robe and his great beard,

9196.52.text:
and his eyes on far-off places. "It is finished,"
he said, and he and the young man parted.

9205.61.text:
And whether he remained a spot of colour and
an anachronism in London, or whether he ever

9210.50.text:
came again to Baghdad, and what dark hands
kept on the circulation of his twenty-five-and-six,

9222.23.text:
Mr. Sladden entered the bare-boarded room
in which he slept and spent all his indoor

9227.58.text:
hours between closing-time and the hour at
which Messrs. Mergin and Chater commenced.

9234.21.text:
To the Penates of so dingy a room his neat
frock-coat must have been a continual wonder.

9241.77.text:
Mr. Sladden took it off and folded it carefully;
and there was the old man's window rather

9247.77.text:
high up in the wall. There had been no window
in that wall hitherto, nor any ornament at

9254.72.text:
all but a small cupboard, so when Mr. Sladden
had put his frock-coat safely away he glanced

9261.96.text:
through his new window. It was where his cupboard
had been in which he kept his tea-things:

9269.05.text:
they were all standing on the table now. When
Mr. Sladden glanced through his new window

9275.72.text:
it was late in a summer's evening; the butterflies
some while ago would have closed their wings,

9281.97.text:
though the bat would scarcely yet be drifting
abroad—but this was in London: the shops

9288.82.text: were shut and street-lamps not yet lighted.

9293.93.text:
Mr. Sladden rubbed his eyes, then rubbed the
window, and still he saw a sky of blazing

9298.76.text:
blue, and far, far down beneath him, so that
no sound came up from it or smoke of chimneys,

9306.65.text:
a mediaeval city set with towers; brown roofs
and cobbled streets, and then white walls

9315.09.text:
and buttresses, and beyond them bright green
fields and tiny streams. On the towers archers

9322.81.text:
lolled, and along the walls were pikemen,
and now and then a wagon went down some old-world

9329.28.text:
street and lumbered through the gateway and
out to the country, and now and then a wagon

9335.92.text:
drew up to the city from the mist that was
rolling with evening over the fields. Sometimes

9341.94.text:
folks put their heads out of lattice windows,
sometimes some idle troubadour seemed to sing,

9348.44.text:
and nobody hurried or troubled about anything.
Airy and dizzy though the distance was, for

9354.38.text:
Mr. Sladden seemed higher above the city than
any cathedral gargoyle, yet one clear detail

9361.49.text:
he obtained as a clue: the banners floating
from every tower over the idle archers had

9369.13.text:
little golden dragons all over a pure white
field.

9375.09.text:
He heard motor-buses roar by his other window,
he heard the newsboys howling.

9380.67.text:
Mr. Sladden grew dreamier than ever after
that on the premises, in the establishment

9386.05.text:
of Messrs. Mergin and Chater. But in one matter
he was wise and wakeful: he made continuous

9393.12.text:
and careful inquiries about the golden dragons
on a white flag, and talked to no one of his

9399.31.text:
wonderful window. He came to know the flags
of every king in Europe, he even dabbled in

9405.15.text:
history, he made inquiries at shops that understood
heraldry, but nowhere could he learn any trace

9412.70.text:
of little dragons or on a field argent. And
when it seemed that for him alone those golden

9420.89.text:
dragons had fluttered he came to love them
as an exile in some desert might love the

9426.50.text:
lilies of his home or as a sick man might
love swallows when he cannot easily live to

9435.14.text:
As soon as Messrs. Mergin and Chater closed,
Mr. Sladden used to go back to his dingy room

9441.43.text:
and gaze though the wonderful window until
it grew dark in the city and the guard would

9447.31.text:
go with a lantern round the ramparts and the
night came up like velvet, full of strange

9455.11.text:
stars. Another clue he tried to obtain one
night by jotting down the shapes of the constellations,

9462.27.text:
but this led him no further, for they were
unlike any that shone upon either hemisphere.

9471.42.text:
Each day as soon as he woke he went first
to the wonderful window, and there was the

9477.36.text:
city, diminutive in the distance, all shining
in the morning, and the golden dragons dancing

9484.20.text:
in the sun, and the archers stretching themselves
or swinging their arms on the tops of the

9490.15.text:
windy towers. The window would not open, so
that he never heard the songs that the troubadours

9497.75.text:
sang down there beneath the gilded balconies;
he did not even hear the belfries' chimes,

9504.19.text:
though he saw the jack-daws routed every hour
from their homes. And the first thing that

9510.28.text:
he always did was to cast his eye round all
the little towers that rose up from the ramparts

9517.14.text:
to see that the little golden dragons were
flying there on their flags. And when he saw

9523.40.text:
them flaunting themselves on white folds from
every tower against the marvelous deep blue

9529.18.text:
of the sky he dressed contentedly, and, taking
one last look, went off to his work with a

9536.52.text:
glory in his mind. It would have been difficult
for the customers of Messrs. Mergin and Chater

9542.97.text:
to guess the precise ambition of Mr. Sladden
as he walked before them in his neat frock-coat:

9549.22.text:
it was that he might be a man-at-arms or an
archer in order to fight for the little golden

9554.43.text:
dragons that flew on a white flag for an unknown
king in an inaccessible city. At first Mr.

9563.64.text:
Sladden used to walk round and round the mean
street that he lived in, but he gained no

9568.76.text:
clue from that; and soon he noticed that quite
different winds blew below his wonderful window

9576.36.text:
from those that blew on the other side of
the house.

9580.08.text:
In August the evenings began to grow shorter:
this was the very remark that the other employees

9587.10.text:
made to him at the emporium, so that he almost
feared that they suspected his secret, and

9593.84.text:
he had much less time for the wonderful window,
for lights were few down there and they blinked

9602.25.text:
One morning late in August, just before he
went to Business, Mr. Sladden saw a company

9607.35.text:
of pikemen running down the cobbled road towards
the gateway of the mediaeval city—Golden

9612.62.text:
Dragon City he used to call it alone in his
own mind, but he never spoke of it to anyone.

9620.21.text:
The next thing that he noticed was that the
archers were handling round bundles of arrows

9625.61.text:
in addition to the quivers which they wore.
Heads were thrust out of windows more than

9630.85.text:
usual, a woman ran out and called some children
indoors, a knight rode down the street, and

9636.71.text:
then more pikemen appeared along the walls,
and all the jack-daws were in the air. In

9643.17.text:
the street no troubadour sang. Mr. Sladden
took one look along the towers to see that

9649.99.text:
the flags were flying, and all the golden
dragons were streaming in the wind. Then he

9656.61.text:
had to go to Business. He took a bus back
that evening and ran upstairs. Nothing seemed

9662.96.text:
to be happening in Golden Dragon City except
a crowd in the cobbled street that led down

9668.92.text:
to the gateway; the archers seemed to be reclining
as usual lazily in their towers, and then

9676.44.text:
a white flag went down with all its golden
dragons; he did not see at first that all

9682.58.text:
the archers were dead. The crowd was pouring
towards him, towards the precipitous wall

9689.40.text:
from which he looked; men with a white flag
covered with golden dragons were moving backwards

9695.82.text:
slowly, men with another flag were pressing
them, a flag on which there was one huge red

9702.97.text:
bear. Another banner went down upon a tower.
Then he saw it all: the golden dragons were

9711.43.text:
being beaten—his little golden dragons.
The men of the bear were coming under the

9717.37.text:
window; what ever he threw from that height
would fall with terrific force: fire-irons,

9723.86.text:
coal, his clock, whatever he had—he would
fight for his little golden dragons yet. A

9732.72.text:
flame broke out from one of the towers and
licked the feet of a reclining archer; he

9738.58.text:
did not stir. And now the alien standard was
out of sight directly underneath. Mr. Sladden

9746.53.text:
broke the panes of the wonderful window and
wrenched away with a poker the lead that held

9751.18.text:
them. Just as the glass broke he saw a banner
covered with golden dragons fluttering still,

9759.18.text:
and then as he drew back to hurl the poker
there came to him the scent of mysterious

9765.42.text:
spices, and there was nothing there, not even
the daylight, for behind the fragments of

9772.87.text:
the wonderful window was nothing but that
small cupboard in which he kept his tea-things.

9780.31.text:
And though Mr. Sladden is older now and knows
more of the world, and even has a Business

9785.84.text:
of his own, he has never been able to buy
such another window, and has not ever since,

9793.40.text:
either from books or men, heard any rumour
at all of Golden Dragon City.

9803.44.text:
Here the fourteenth Episode of the Book of
Wonder endeth and here the relating of the

9810.09.text:
Chronicles of Little Adventures at the Edge
of the World. I take farewell of my readers.

9816.53.text:
But it may be we shall even meet again, for
it is still to be told how the gnomes robbed

9822.07.text:
the fairies, and of the vengeance that the
fairies took, and how even the gods themselves

9828.21.text:
were troubled thereby in their sleep; and
how the King of Ool insulted the troubadours,

9834.59.text:
thinking himself safe among his scores of
archers and hundreds of halberdiers, and how

9841.03.text:
the troubadours stole to his towers by night,
and under his battlements by the light of

9846.97.text:
the moon made that king ridiculous for ever
in song. But for this I must first return

9853.33.text:
to the Edge of the World. Behold, the caravans
start.
